Modification_Detail.description: Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID Changed LIDs from urn:nasa:pds: to urn:esa:psa:
Updated schema version. Adding missing "agency" references. Description updated.

External_Reference.reference_text: Boggess, A., Bohlin, R.C., Evans, D.C., Freeman, H.R., Gull, T.R., Heap, S.R., Klinglesmith, D.A., Longanecker, G.R., Sparks, W., West, D.K., Holm, A.V., Perry, P.M., Schiffer III, F.H., Turnrose, B.E., Wu, C.C., Lane, A.L., Linsky, J.L., Savage, B.D., Benvenuti, P., Cassatella, A.,Clavel, J., Heck, A., Macchetto,F., Penston, M.V., Selvelli, C.I., Dunford, E., Gondhaleker, P., Oliver, M.B., Sandford, M.C.W., Stickland, D., Boksenberg, A., Coleman, C.I., Snijders, M.A.J., Wilson, R., In-Flight Performance of the IUE, Nature, 275, 377, 1978.

Instrument_Host.name: INTERNATIONAL ULTRAVIOLET EXPLORER
Instrument_Host.description: The IUE satellite was launched on January 26, 1978, into an elliptical geosynchronous orbit, primarily monitored and operated from Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) for 16 hours daily, while the European Space Agency manages it for 8 hours from the Villafranca Satellite Tracking Station (VILSPA) in Spain. The satellite's power comes from solar panels, supplemented by batteries during Earth shadow periods. IUE has three-axis stabilization with a nominal pointing accuracy of 1 arc-second, controlled by an on-board computer (OBC) that manages operations and data from gyros. Following a gyro failure, a backup system now includes a Fine Sun Sensor (FSS) for attitude control. The spacecraft maneuvers using reaction wheels and hydrazine jets. At the Telescope Operations Center (TOC), the Telescope Operator, under the supervision of a Resident Astronomer, manages scientific operations and spacecraft functions. Data is transmitted to ground stations, processed, and displayed for monitoring. Regular station-keeping maneuvers ensure the satellite's orbit remains accessible to ground antennas.
